bibl.title: Notes from Liberian Legation In U.S. to Department of State, 1862-1898 T807

body.div1:
1039 Lambard Street Philadelphia, Pa November 20th 1890.
Honorable James G. Blaine Secretary of State Washington D.C.
Sir,
In the short interview with which you honored me, on Friday last, I informed you that I was commissioned by the President of Liberia to approach your Government, with the hope that you would be induced to make such a demonstration in our favor as will prevent foreign nations from making encroachments* on our territory.
Unfortunately for me the pressure of business did not permit of your giving me time to lay before you the facts, and you tell me to call again the next day, which I did, and I called again on the following Monday and Tuesday but with no better success awing to the *frat pressure of business in your office.
As I had to leave your city and on
Tuesday
Tuesday last, I make bold to adopt this method of laying the matter before you, trusting that you will be kind enough to give it you consideration.
In the year 1885 a French Man of war came into the harbor of our Capital, Mourview*, and the Commander called upon the President. During the conversation the Commander said that he had stopped at Beoiby*- a place within our boundray line- and had an interview with the chiefs. The President asked, "Why did you stop them and have that interview, do you not know that territory belongs to Liberia"! The Commander replied that he did not know that it belonged to Liberia, and that he has been instemeted* by his government to stop them and ban that interview.
After the department of the resvel* the President instmeted our Representative in Paris to call the attentionof this officer, and to point out the fact that our boundray on the South East **terided to the san Pedro River, as you will see by referring to the "Imperial Atlas" in your office, and that they had ritually admitted it by their Naval Charts and otherwise*
The French Government then claimed that they had Commercial Treaties with the chief of Beniby* as old as 1846, I think, but we have seeds* of Cossive of that Territory made to us as far back as 1836 or 1837.
We laid this matter before your government and asked for your kind offices; and in a despatch to Mr. McLorne, dated Janurary 13th, 1886 Mr. Boyard instmeted him to interview, and to say to the French Government. "We excerise no protertorate over Liberia, but the circumstances that that Republic originated through thr colonization of American citizens, and was established under the fastering caneton** of this government, gives us the right, as the next friend of Liberia, to aid her in preventing any encrroachments* of Foreign powers on her territorial soverengnity, and in settling any dispute that may
arise
arise. The Southeasternly boundary at the River San Pedro has never been questioned and has the powerful sanctions of general admission for many years".
This matter has remained in obyeance as ever auppar*-oince that time; but if lately came to our knowledge that one Captain Bingen, who was a pominent officer in the late expedition against the King of Dahomey, claims to have made expllorations in the near and Southeast of Liberia; and he has published in a "Suppliment and Journal Le Temps, Mans 1890", a map representing Liberia on a very narrow strip along the Coast and representing the Country in the immediate near of Liberia, as fas as Musada**, as unexplored country, and liable to become a Proletorate* of France although our Mr. Beny Anderson had explored that country as far as Musadu** and published an account of his journey- and cutting off our territory on the Southeast up to the Cavalla River, thus taking the very territory in dispute and which Mr. Boyard
belongs
belongs to u by "The powerful sanction* of general admission for many years". The territory so taken from us is represented on his Map as French territory.
Whilst the French have not, as yet made any open movement towards taking possession of our territories, yt. Mr. Secretary, under these circumstances we feel warrants in appealing to your government as "Liberia's next Friend" and asking you to make such a demonstration in our favor as will prevent Foreign government from making such encroachment* on our territory. If your powerful government would make a present of one o your smallest stream form boats to be used in boarding* our Coast from foreigners and preventing them from settling at points remote from our civilized settlements, and tampering with the aboriginals, we feel that over territorial limits will not be encroached* uproar.
My Secretary my Government believes that if you will be followed to give us the benefit of your kind office, and will *induce This Excellency, the President to recommend the giving of this resent* to Liberia we of all be successful; and the very recommencer nation by the President will indicate to the world the friendship of the United States for our Little Republic.
Trusting, Mr Secretary that you will bring this matter to the notice of his Excellency, the President, and that
